I had a reservation at 7:00 pm. I wasn't seated until around 7:40. It also seemed as if they were short on cooks because our table sat for a significant amount of time before the cook showed up. Subsequently, we didn't eat until 8:45. I prefer Ichiban.

Pretty good sushi spot in the city downtown. We ended up ordering way to much food then got huge puppy bellies. But the food was so good! I loved the sushi, miso soup and fried shrimp. Our chef was really cool too. Plus our waiter was super helpful with our huge group.

Not impressed. Save yourself from being "nickeled and dimed" and go to Ichiban where you get more food at better prices. An up charge for fried rice??! Really??  It's a hibachi!  No noodles or it's another charge. Our chef was slow and i had to remind him of items I ordered and did not get. Ichiban has a better atmosphere, better food, and better prices.

We visited for lunch the other day and we were quite satisfied. Our server was super friendly and prompt. My husband and I are what I like to call fake-sushi fans, so we got a California Roll and a Spicy California Roll cuz we were feeling craaaazy that day. We also ordered the coconut shrimp. Everything came out in a reasonable amount of time, although the shrimp came out a couple minutes AFTER our sushi, and I would have preferred it before.  The sushi was well prepared and very tasty. The rolls stuck together just right and had good flavors. The sauce on the spicy rolls had just the right amount of heat. I know, there's not much to a California roll, but what can I say? We're sushi wimps. The coconut shrimp was nearly on par with Red Lobster's coconut shrimp (which are the best coconut shrimp out there) but a teensy bit dry. This was remedied by the yummy, spicy sauce on the side (strangely reminiscent of the sweet chili sauce McDonald's had out during the Olympics...)  All in all the service was great and we enjoyed our food, so we'll be back. The lunch hibachi prices are very reasonable so we hope to try that next time.
Crazy good dinner Yum yum sauce on everything!! Filet mignon love
The food here is soooooooo GROSS NOW!!! Don't eat here... The chef SUCKX
The very first place i ever got to try sushi at, and i ordered a few different rolls too. I liked all the ones i tried. The shrimp tempura was delicious too!

Went here with my BFF for her birthday. Cocktails were great, just a little heavy on the sour mix.  I got the house Cosmo and my friend had the French Kiss cocktail.  The French Kiss was tastier than mine.  I loved the atmosphere: dim lighting, a swanky bar and hibachi tables in the back.  Self seating around the bar so we didn't have to wait at all at 9pm on a Saturday night. Rolls are big and are a decent price and the fish is super fresh. Two of the rolls tasted exactly the same which was a little disappointing: the Hawaii roll and the Haiku roll. If you want more variety don't order them together. Overall, Would recommend!!

Over rated.  In most cases you get what you pay for except here, you pay more for average at best sushi.  The waitress had a terrible attitude and a face to match.  Yokoso is shitting on this place.  Not to mention have fun trying to find a decent parking spot on the southside.

The fascination with Nakama has always left me confused. I'm not a huge hibachi fan, so my gripes truly rest with the sushi. As far as sushi goes, Nakama simply doesn't deserve the praise that it gets. Granted, when they first opened, the food was decent, but even back then it was never a truly great sushi place.  Now, if you like your sushi over-saturated in sauces, then you might enjoy it, but all too often, the rolls are soggy, poorly rolled, and the fish quality isn't as good as you'd expect if you were judging the restaurant from the outside. Blame it on the pace with which the chefs have to prepare it...blame it on them hiring inexperienced sushi chefs. Whatever it is, it's just not up to par with some of the other sushi places in Pittsburgh. In fact, the sushi at the Tokyo Buffet on McKnight is just as good...AND THAT'S A BUFFET!  Regardless, it's always packed, and I'm a huge fan of seeing businesses succeed in town, but Nakama is truly a place that's gained too much from its trendy status. Unfortunately, I'm all about the food, so after you enjoy a good martini and enjoy the little hibachi show, what you're left with is the reality that the food is second priority to those other two parts.  The hibachi is fine, but it's nothing special...of course, when is hibachi ever truly a special experience, taste-wise? It's just a buttery fried rice fest in your mouth. The best hibachi I've ever had at Nakama was the ahi tuna...the cut of fish was actually fresher than sashimi that I've ordered there, and keeping it seared, but rare in the middle kept it from drying out. Or maybe that was just the butter...either way, it's by far the one thing that I've walked away with good feelings about.  The sashimi cuts that I've had have rarely satisfied. Fresh fish shouldn't taste so fishy, and for what you pay, they should be serving up better cuts. The sushi menu is interesting enough that you'll be able to find what you're looking for, but it's truly a hit-or-miss experience when the sushi hits your taste buds.  Overall, Nakama is the hot spot where you meet your friends before hitting the clubs and make random friends over some happy hour drinks, but if you're looking for a quality meal, I'd enjoy the drinks and move on to any number of better restaurants nearby.

Nakama is my go-to for special occasions! Hibachi is great with all kinds of land and sea options to choose from.  Sushi is also just spectacular with so many different choices! However, being that nakama is in the Southside - where all the bars and club scenes are, it may seem like more of a bar type environment rather than a sushi and hibachi restaurant.  Reasoning why it doesn't get a full 5 stars is due to how expensive it can be! Dinner for 2,  a person can easily spend 60-70$ during dinner time.  That's why I like to hit the lunch time special where it's half the price - but also half the food but you still get your hibachi fix!

DISCLAIMER: I've only ever tried the sushi. I have no clue about the hibatchi bar.  I was delighted to see that I'm not the only one who finds this place to be completely overrated and overpriced. The sushi was your average run of the mill raw fish. Nothing special about the freshness or the imaginitivity of the rolls. That is, except for the price. I couldn't believe that a meal for such average sushi cost as much as it did.   If you're looking for some decent raw fish to feed your sushi craving, try Chaya in Squirrel Hill instead. You won't regret it.

If you want Benihana's in Pittsburgh, I guess this is the place to go. Other than the fact that they have some marketing and advertising genius who's greased the palms of every "guide to the city" and "best restaurants" free pamphlet that they hand out at hotel concierge desks, I don't know what all the hype's about.   They have a big sushi bar area, and quite a few grills in the back. We sat at a table with some PITT football players and I ordered the filet, while TY got surf and turf. It was all kind of eh, but I have to say that customer service was very good and all the staff were really nice. The filet was tender, but I think just the flavor of everything was mediocre, especially at their prices. We had a coupon for $15 in one of the aforementioned guide books, so pick one of those up before you spend your money here.

I've been such a fan of Nakama but lately things have gone down hill. I make a trip to this location once a month/every other month, and have for years. I've noticed some changes for at least the past year. Portion sizes decreasing, prices increasing, and service hitting rock bottom--quality of food is about the only constant.  The food and location are awesome. Food tastes fresh and well made. Being located on East Carson is awesome, easy to get to with valet parking and street parking available.  Now where it drops off; prices of food have steadily inclined whereas portions are decreasing. Once you'd expect to leave with left overs, now you're lucky with 8 pieces of shrimp in your dinner. Also, the cost of something as minor as having fried rice over steamed rice is nearly $4. But it is worth it considering the past two outings the steamed rice wasn't delivered to the table until after the meal was prepared.   Lastly, the service really needs an overhaul. As someone who has experience in the service industry I know how it is and sometimes you're having an off/bad day but MAN IS IT BAD. From the hostess to our waiter (with exception of the chef--they're typically wonderful!) it feels like everyone is in a rush and no one cares to help you even when placing a food order.   Two of my most recent trips resulting in forgetting to fill out drink/bar order. I can understand waiting on the bartender but water shouldn't take more than 10 minutes. Both of these outings were on Monday nights when the restaurant is at its slowest.   One waitress over charged us on fried rice, no big deal, but then argued that the three of us in our party ordered it while only one did. It took too long to resolve we almost wished we didn't speak up.  Last night our service was even worse, again waiting for the server to arrive, 10 minutes for water, forgetting one water and ignoring the table until our dinner was being cooked. Then it was each time we'd ask for something he would run away. No water refill, no soy sauce, going to the bar to get a container. I can understand on a Friday night but a slow Monday?   I hope this place improves because I really do enjoy it but for the price I'd prefer to spend my money elsewhere

took my family out going off the name. the restaurant in south side has a great reputation. it turns out this place had made no improvement since its previous life as a poor excuse for hibachi. waited a good twenty minutes for the server to take our drink order. after about another twenty minutes and hearing loud complaints from two other tables the server returned and placed a take out box on the grill. it melted immediately. drinks had not come along with her so we decided to walk out. went down the road to ichiban and head awesome service and food as usual.

Decent Hibachi food. Solid 3 stars.  My boyfriend and I came to Katama for a Hibachi dinner on a Wednesday night. We have high expectations when it comes to Hibachi because our taste buds have been acquired to meet the Hibachi standards of Nakato in Atlanta, however I will TRY my best to give an unbiased opinion.  To start off, Nakama was fairly empty for a Hibachi restaurant. We were seated immediately after arriving and ordered drinks. I orders the Slush Puppie which I thought would be a frozen mixed drink but instead it was not frozen at all and tasted like a melted Blue Raspberry Slushie from Quick Trip. For entrees, I ordered the Teryaki  chicken and my boyfriend ordered the Shrimp and Chicken. We noticed that the prices were on the more expensive side ranging from $18-40 with an additional charge of $3.75 for fries rice.  Our Hibachi chef came out moments later looking a bit unenthused and seemed to be new to the Hibachi grill. I sat patiently waiting for the big fire opening at the beginning of every Hibachi experience but this time it didn't happen. Our chef started right on the appetizers! I ordered the Shrimp appetizer which was pretty standard, and my boyfriend opted for the mushroom appetizer which was yummy. Next up came the vegetables lacking in flavor.. I ended up having to sprinkle my veggies with soy sauce for taste. The fried rice tasted a little off to me as well, as if it were cooked with margarine instead of the traditional Hibachi seasoned butter. Our entrees were decent but well portioned with enough to take home for left overs.   Overall, their Hibachi recipes lack in flavor and seasoning. The prices are comparable to Benihana's however the portion sizes provide enough for left overs.

The cranberry location doesn't really live up to the swankier south side locale. It's very tight at the teppanyaki tables in the back, I feel like they tried to stuff as many tables and chairs as possible into a small space, so you are definitely bumping elbows with your neighbors if all the chairs are filled and it's tough to navigate. Service was quick and friendly. Our chef was highly entertaining and my 87 year-old grandmother described the shrimp as "the best she had ever eaten".  The sushi rolls were good, fresh and flavorful. The scallops and shrimp Diablo were barely spicy. I could have used a whole lot more heat. But the scallops were cooked well, not gummy at all, which is a huge accomplishment!  All in all I would probably return to make grandma happy, but not unless she was with us

Went on a Monday at 8PM and the restaurant and Hibachi wasn't very crowded.  Monday also gives you $7 off the steak/chicken/shrimp dinner; which is a good deal.  I decided to try the restaurant again and my opinion stayed the same.  Onion soup is watery and not very good.  The salad dressing is not as good as other similar places.  The show is nothing special.    If you go to their website you can get a free appetizer coupon but you can't use with the daily special.  No valet on Mondays but many meters are on Carson St.
Love this place - good food decent price! Great times!

Great place for sushi. Always fresh and quickly served.   Seating for sushi is open which can be a bit awkward when it is busy. I've never had to wait long though, if at all. Be prepared to wait for the valet though, may as well try to park on your own.

I went here on a Friday night to celebrate my boyfriends new job. We didn't want to drive downtown,so I figured nakama in Wexford would be a nice place for a celebration. The service and staff we're very friendly. My boyfriend got sushi and he said it was fantastic. But the hibachi dinner, not so much. The salad was drenched in dressing and everything that came off the grill was extremely salty. It made it really hard/impossible to eat. The cook and waitress were so nice, I didn't want to say anything. I was a little upset because we spent so much money on dinner, I wish the quality would have been better. Overall I think this place is way too expensive for the quality and amount of food you get. You would be better off getting a groupon for another hibachi place. Next time I think we will make the drive downtown to go out for a celebration dinner.

I really like Nakama and I've been here several times. I am surprised the ratings aren't better actually. I think it's a good place to get good sushi and hibachi. I've never had any of the other food so I can't speak for anything else. I've never had a bad experience but have also never been blown away by anything crazy.  Seating is available at the sushi counter, bar, hibachi table and dining room. It gets very busy and crowded on weekends so I recommend a reservation if you have a larger group.  It can get loud as well especially in the evening on weekends so I wouldn't come here during that time if you want a quiet and intimate environment.  Overall a good choice in my opinion and I will be back at some point.

My wife and I have been visited this establishment during the day, and on a Saturday night.  I am not expect on Japanese food, but I like what I had.  I am out of Atlanta, so the prices are great.  Nice place to start a Saturday night out, and nice for a business meal.

I've been to Nakama a few times for sushi (always delicious), but I finally got to try the hibachi .   The deal is pretty good -- you pick the protein (or veggies) and you get that, fried rice, salad, and a mini appetizer of (2) shrimp.  In addition to the hibachi scallops, I ordered the Nakama ceviche appetizer. When it arrived I was a bit thrown because, while it was a very pretty plate, it wasn't what I would call ceviche. Instead, it was a few large pieces of tuna sashimi on a bed of raw white onion, carrots, and I believe jicama. There wasn't much citrus flavor at all and the raw white onion was a bit too much. The tuna was delicious, but I would definitely change the name of the item.  The hibachi scallops were cooked perfectly, and the fried rice accompaniment was a little too good (I watched lots of butter go into it). Very yummy.  As far as the hibachi performance went, there wasn't much, though it was 12pm on a Saturday, so I get it. Our chef was very nice and kept up some good conversation with us. I also greatly enjoyed the fireball he started off with (see picture).

Been hearing about this place and love my sushi, so finally indulged myself.  It's a Friday evening about 6pm and the place is hopping with people and their energy (and noise level).  However, since I'm going solo tonight I have no problem finding a place at the sushi bar.  I'm tended to promptly and pleasantly by my server who helps me determine which tuna I would prefer for my sushi selection and lets me know it is very fresh tonight.  I end up with eel, salmon, and tuna plus a salad with ginger dressing and a glass of plum wine.    My server checks on me, the sushi chef at the sushi bar serves me my sushi and it is a nice portion and tastes very fresh and just the right serving temperature.  I'm a happy camper as I do love my sushi.  The price is in line with any sushi restaurant.  I spent about $32.00 plus tip for 6 pieces of sushi, a salad, and a glass of wine.  They do have the hibachi tables and usual fare and fanfare that goes with it.  Plusses:  No TV in the sushi bar and no salt and pepper shakers alongside the soy sauces.  :-)  Been seeing that a lot lately so was glad it wasn't the case here.  The only down side is the volume level of noise which I would attribute to poor acoustics, perhaps?  Not a problem for me dining alone but if I was with someone and wanted to carry on a conversation, I think there would have been a lot of "Huh?  What'd you say?;s".    I'd definitely come here again.

While this is still primarily a Japanese hibachi, it is clearly better than the numerous chains that have been popping up everywhere. The major difference being the quality of the ingredients and cooks. My steak and seafood is always cooked perfectly to temperature, which can be spotty at some of the competitors. Also, I would rate the sushi here among the best in Pittsburgh. Also you can get some menu items you just don't find elsewhere. I particularly like the Diablo preparation with a spicy sauce and soba noodles.   The one knock would be the showmanship can be pretty hit or miss here depending who you get and there is really no innovation. A pretty standard show.
Great restaurant!The food was perfect.The cook was funny,friendly,told us funny stories while his cooking! Delicious!

Good sushi! The price wasn't cheap, but the quality was worth it. The issue is space. There are people who come solely for the bar, but there isn't enough space. I had some blonde chick shaking her hair in my saki! It was so bad that the waitress had to ask her and her friends to either sit or move away from the table. It was ridiculous. I rate on both product and atmosphere. The food was superb, the drinks delicious but Nakama needs to fix their atmosphere. The  sports bar/ bar environment does not suit this place well. It's sexy  and classy, they need to keep the drama away. Food saved this place.

The 3 stars is strictly for the Laura the bartender and the daytime atmosphere, not the food.  I've been to Nakama a handful of times, though only once was it specifically for food. The rest of the time it was for a few drinks or some sake because it was a nice day out and I like sitting near their windows. I've never ordered a specialty drink, only beer and sake. Tip: if you go and like sake, get the Crazy Milk and check out the bottle for a few lulz.  We've ordered food twice, I believe, one time being referenced above when it was a full meal and the order was just some sushi for tapas-style appetizers. Neither time has the food impressed me. In fact, it's probably the worst sushi I have ever had. My boyfriend ordered a spicy tuna roll and the tuna looked like baby food, as if someone had chewed it up and spit it back out - no lie. It was disgusting, but he powered through most of it as he was starving. They also managed to mess up fried rice, completely annihilating the veggies for some reason. The sushi rolls I've ordered have ranged from "eh" to "gross."  I can't give this place less than 3 stars, though, because every time I've gone I've had a really great time. I guess I would break down my review like this: Food - 1 star, Atmosphere - 4 stars, Service - 4 stars.

My husband and I went here today to celebrate our anniversary, we were there in the afternoon because of our work schedules. We had an amazing time!! Even though it was still "lunch time " they fired up the hibachi table for just the two of us! Luke was our chef, and he was awesome!! We had a blast, and we'll definitely be back!! Also, the prices for the lunch menu were discounted, win win in my book!!

Literally my favorite Japanese place ever.  I love sushi, but my boyfriend isn't a huge fan, so I got the Boston roll and he got the steak tips. AMAZING.  We no longer live in the area, but we always visit it when we're in town.
The sushi was delicious. A bit pricey, but it tasted awesome. We got several rolls and shared them. Overall, we enjoyed it and would definitely return.

Went for lunch with my friend. We sat at the Hibachi table and had the best time. We come here regularly but today was exceptionally awesome because of our chef's upbeat personality and witty jokes the whole time. Our chef, Luke, was entertaining as well as cooked everything perfectly. Would request his table again in the future. Also ordered a Philly roll, which are always delicious here. The veggie egg roll we got was actually pretty disgusting. It was so oily and tasted bitter. I told the waitress and she gladly removed from my bill. Other than that, lunch was great.

I've had pretty good sushi in the NY / NJ area and this would definitely be a place we'd go on the regular, so for the people of Pittsburgh PA, you guys deff have good sushi in town. Not only was the sushi good, but a great selection of beers, and a cool sports bar feel. Really hip, not something I expected in Pitt, very NYC like.   My one comment would be on a Sunday during Football Season, nobody want's to see pirate baseball on tv, especially regular season baseball.

Love hibachi but not this place! Way more expensive then it's competitors for less food and poor service. The manager wasn't even aware of the open table coupon we earned from spending so many points at various places; made us out $20 dollars. Also took the server 20+ minutes to refill drinks. Sad!!

5 people. No booze. $200. Was the food remarkable? No. Was it acceptable? Yes. Was it difficult to see in the low-light ambiance? Yes. Are there alternatives? Certainly. Do I think this place is a bit over rated? Sorta, kinda, yes.
Sushi was average. I ate at the bar & the service was poor..very rushed; non attentive..had 2 ask for utensils 3x to 3 different staff, had to ask for soy dish..and no meal follow-up.
Good hibachi for Pitt.  Good tasty food, large portions and trendy environment.  I would recommended for group dinners, business travel dinners and Happy Hour.  Enjoy!

Huge sushi rolls which were a little hard to pick up with chopsticks without them falling apart. Interesting combos of contemporary ingredients. We had the spider roll which came with huge pieces of crispy fried soft shell crab. Hamachi and jalapeno roll was good too. I can't remember the other two rolls we had but all the fish tasted fresh.   We didn't order hibachi but it (the hibachi) looked kind of weak compared to other places I've been, not much of a show, no interaction between chef and guests, etc. Mostly just the chef tapping the spatula, no flipping, tossing, no onion volcano! Glad we just stuck with the sushi.

One of the best sushi places in Pittsburgh. Only problem is that it is usually very crowded and the noise is not well isolated, so sometimes it is hard to talk over dinner. Also, tables for sushi are too small and too close to each other. But food is outstanding, especially specialty rolls and fried rice at hibachi tables

The Sushi is really good! The Hibachi is also very flavorful, staff is friendly. The only downside of this restaurant is that it is super packed on weekends (just like all of the other popular restaurants). The spicy chicken egg rolls are really soooo good! Also, my family members that hate sushi actually really liked all of the tempura rolls.

This is my second time visiting the restaurant down on the Southside and I have to say that the food was fantastic as usual, but this visit this time around the service by our waitress(Haley) was mediocre. My friend ordered a wine(Pinot Noir) but she came back with a Pinot Grigio, which is a common mistake and not too much of a big deal. But when she was asked to take back the drink she got snippy with us. She also had out chef confused with what she has written down and our food was going to the wrong plate. The occasion was my friends birthday and when another one of her friends came by she didn't want to take his drink order. She completely messed up our payments and got snippy with us when we were confused. Our overall experience with Haley was terrible. The only reason why I tipped her 20% was because I am also a server and know the struggle. The food was delicious and yum yum sauce is great, which is why I still recommend this place and love coming here when in town.

Note: for sushi bar. Did not go for Hibachi (because I've had enough of Benihana and it seemed really pricey). Wait was also nonexistent for sushi at the bar.   Another disclaimer: I'm used to California sushi restaurants & chains (Japanese friends would have MUCH higher standards) and I haven't had good sushi since I've moved out to DC.  Friend & I shared: Pittsburgh Penguins Roll (when in Pittsburgh...), Spicy Squid Salad, Salmon Ceviche (cannot find on online menu), and Philadelphia roll (because somehow my friend has NEVER had it?)  Everything was really good! I especially liked the spicy squid salad and the salmon ceviche- the latter had pretty thick pieces of salmon but was so nicely presented that I didn't really mind at all (the same cannot be said for everyone.)   Overall: good, solid Japanese restaurant. Would go again.
Very busy at lunch.  Almost like they weren't ready for a Friday lunch.  Slow service, mediocre food.  I think I will skip this place the next time I am in town...
Good sushi, perhaps a little pricey, but always good.  Hibachi is excellent as well - great chefs, entertaining.

Trendy and overpriced as it may be, I'm a Nakama fan. Best hibachi in the city, and the atmosphere has more of a modern-feel than competitors like Ichiban or SAGA. We had a large group (about 20 people) there for my birthday dinner this year, and the service was great. The chefs put on a great show and everyone had a good time. We also had my sisters bachelorette party at the one in the South Side and it was a success. Recommend for a fun occasion.

A Saturday night out in Pittsburgh should start at Nakama for no reason other than entertainment (and good cocktails).  The place was packed, but we found a space by the bar in the corner.  We didn't get a chance to eat the food, but I can say the place looks kind of fun.  Not really date worthy as it was pretty loud, but the hibachi style dining is definitely a conversation starter.  I ordered a strawberry citrus-tini, a serious $10 cocktail.  In Philly, I wouldn't think twice about this price, but for the burgh, it seemed a bit steep.  It was quite tasty though and I couldn't really stop myself from licking the flavored sugar on the rim.    Nakama is like the serengeti...it is hunt or be hunted.  Ladies brought their A game, or should I say DD game as most everyone in the place had their breasts on display.  We joked about a possible nipple slip...quite frankly, I wouldn't have been surprised.  The gents are just as preened as the ladies and I couldn't help but see that the Jersey Shore had made it all the way across PA.  Fist pumping anyone?  We only stayed for the one cocktail, but we were there long enough for some decent people watching.  I would suggest going for the beginning of your evening on Carson St.  I know I certainly learned a lot about the singles scene in my short time there.

There are not many sushi options in the area.  I do not eat raw fish, and I'm not looking for anything fancy - so I go for the Baked Alaskan Roll. It's good. I do return for this roll and the hibachi dinners every once and awhile. The overall experience at Nakama is just lackluster. Nakama is extremely overpriced at $7-8 for a domestic craft beer, $9-13 for a glass of domestic wine. They are extremely slow. The servers are disinterested. My visit last week was the only time I had a friendly, non-snooty waiter. Every other visit I've been treated to snooty service. They have a great rewards program and I will return twice a year with my complimentary meal (up to $20) coupon :) I appreciate this aspect of their business model.

I don't give many two star reviews, but this place deserves it. Lesson learned after dining here: trust Yelp reviews. Say it with me now, trust...Yelp...reviews....  Where to start? Let's start with the positives: Service was good, ambiance is great if you're looking for a fun (read: loud, energetic atmosphere), and the Miso soup.  Negatives: I paid $25 per person for overcooked, chewy steak and tasteless shrimp. I decided to fill up on Sapporo, salad, rice and veggies and find the first homeless person to give my leftovers to.  If you're looking for Hibachi in Pittsburgh there are other places that you should check out first. I can't comment on the sushi as we didn't order any.

My friend loves Nakama so when she came to visit me, we decided to get dinner here. We ordered sushi and appetizer to share. The sushi was decent but overall, not very memorable. If you want authentic sushi, I highly recommend Chaya in Squirrel Hill!

I really do love Nakama. The food is delicious & something about watching it made & set out on your plate is a good feeling.. Everything is so fresh. I live when the cons do their little tricks. I do feel like they have made the portions smaller & I wish they gave you the extra mushrooms & the end.

I personally never had the hibachi, I like to sit up at the bar. Its usually pretty hard to find a seat but if you are patient and come with only 1 other person, its usually doable.   The rolls are actually very fresh, and very delicious. I eat a lot of sushi and I would definetly say this is fresh fish. I would also add that the rolls are very creative... i have never had a roll that I am not satisfied with.  There is also a great atmosphere as usually it is loud, lots of people, TV's everywhere for watching the game. They also have pretty good service!   I definetly love coming to this place, if only it didn't take so long to find a seat!

We had reservations for four people on a Saturday night at 8:00. We did not get seated until 9:00. In the bathroom I heard the hostess complaining about how backed up they were and that she wanted to tell the complaining guests "I don't know you, I don't care". This attitude aside, the rest of our service was really good. It was slow-going on getting drinks, but I could tell our server was really rushed. Hats off to the people at our "grill" who were going to the bar to buy drinks. It gets hectic at hibachi places, and they did a pretty good job for being as busy as they were. Our hibachi chef was awesome and adorable. He was really a lot of fun, and you could tell he knew what he was doing.  The drinks were reasonably priced, as was the menu. I think it was about $45.00 for me by myself with a hibachi meal and two Kettle One cocktails. The shrimp was good, and the steak was really tender. The fried rice was definitely not the best hibachi-fried rice I have ever had, but it hit the spot. I really liked their miso soup, it didn't have tofu, which made me happy!  I would love to go back and try the sushi, although I will probably avoid coming here during a peak hour, whether or not I have reservations. Definitely better than Benihana, although I have had better hibachi.

I have been to Nakama, many many times.  I usually just get sushi or maki.  You cant complain about this aspect of Nakama.  They always have good, fresh, tasty rolls.   It isn't the cheapest, but how cheap to you want sushi grade fish? They are good size portions too, so its not like your paying all for the presentation.  They move a lot of fish here, so it's unlikely you will get subpar seafood. The Dragon roll is awesome and I usually get the Caterpillar as well.  both nice sized rolls.  They do have hibachi in the back  but I've never tried that.
They've gotten better. It's still location, location, location. I can't blame them for charging the prices they do- people are paying it and leaving happy.

Trendy ambiance, fresh sushi, but the worst hibachi I've ever had.  First with my sushi review: I have been here multiple times for sushi and liked the bar set up and thought the sushi tasted fresh and the service was quick. Good for happy hours (especially Thursday specials) or dates. However I don't like how if you only want to order sushi you have to sit at the bar. It makes it impossible to go there as a group or you end up waiting forever if there aren't enough seats in the bar area.. when the entire back room could be open.   The reason for my 2-star review is the hibachi, something that is pretty standardized among restaurants, but Nakama didn't have any of it right the time I went. The miso soup tasted like the packet cup of soup you buy in college. I ordered the shrimp and it turned out tough and rubbery. I also tried some of my friend's steak, which was also well done and dry. The hibachi chef didn't even ask how she wanted it to be cooked. Also, even though it's similarly priced to other hibachi restaurants, you have to up charge for fried rice and don't even have the option of noodles.  Bottomline: go to Nakama in small groups for sushi but stay away from the Hibachi

I ordered delivery through Uber eats.  My food arrived a mess, which is most likely not the restaurant's fault so I let that slide and will take that up with Uber.  However, I ordered hibachi meals, 3 of them.  I also ordered sushi as well.  I received no sauce with my order.  No soy sauce, shrimp sauce or steak sauce.  I called the restaurant, because this is their mistake and spoke with a manager named Sum or Sam, I couldn't make out her name due to the noise in the background.  I explained the issue and she told me to come and pick it up.  No apology or otherwise for the mistake.  I explained that I ordered delivery because I didn't have a means to pick it up at this time, and she said oh well.  At that point she said, well I'm not going to keep discussing the same thing and hung up on me.  I called back in and am currently waiting for an owner to contact me.  A simple I'm sorry goes a long way, further more don't offer delivery through a third party if you can't provide the items that are supposed to come with an order.  I won't be going to this establishment or ordering from them again.

I worked at a top notch sushi restaurant and was educated very well with the real definition of sushi over summer. and having come back to pittsburgh and eating at nakama, i was sadly disappointed. no one knows what they're serving and it's just a trendy place that pretends to serve sushi for people to say they "eat sushi". the drinks and bar section is fun and the tvs are great for games. but i would not go back there for any food any time soon.

I sat at the sushi bar, which has a great atmosphere.  The sushi rolls were tasty, and there was a fairly large selection. Overall, Nakama was good.  It's definitely one of the better sushi places in Pittsburgh, but it also definitely lacks the charm of a restaurant that I would call one of my favorites.  Nakama gets very crowded Thursday - Saturday nights, so get there early if you don't want to wait an hour or more for a seat.

Let me start with what works at Nakama: The servers. They're super nice and efficient.  What doesn't work is the food, the prices, the crowds, the incredibly busy, loud bar without the possibility of being seated in the quieter room (reserved only for Habachi eaters) -- even when you're paying $15.00/person FOR LUNCH!  And, the restaurant demands that you dress in nice casual wear. No t-shirts, yet the food was terrible!  We shared the Spider Roll and the Chicken and Shrimp Habachi plate, as well as a seaweed salad. The salad was okay. The Spider Roll came in a sticky, overly-sweet sauce which ruined the flavor. The crab was rubbery and seemed old. The chicken Habachi was waaaaaaay overcooked (dry to the point of being hard to swallow),  the shrimp smelled old , and it was NOT DEVEINED (read: it still had the poop tunnel in it!). ICK! This is supposed to be Pittsburgh's finest sushi restaurant? Old fish meets overcooked chicken, meets truly bad sushi, meets loud bar with no option to sit elsewhere (even when you're not drinking), meets overpriced lunch menu!  My advice: Go elsewhere! If you want something to eat, check out ANY other restaurant in the South Side. Even if it's bad, it won't be as expensive as Nakama. But, there are better places to be had in Pittsburgh. Not being from the area, I can't speak for sushi bars, but,  I especially like The Gypsy Cafe and Primanti's in the South Side. Cheers!

I like hibachi but I forgot how expensive the fancy stuff were. With that in mind and my budget, I decided to get an assortment of sushi rolls and a signature cocktail. The sushi and coconut shrimp were great, but the cocktail was just a tease. It honestly tasted like juice. Maybe the light up ice cube was placed to detract you from the lack of alcohol.

I'm usually not a fan of hibachi in general, but I see why Nakama is a favorite for most. Authentic tasting asian hibachi cuisine and atmosphere make this place a sure bet. Conveniently located on the corner of Carson and 18th, Nakama is a popular destination for those looking for sushi and the famous hibachi-grilled meals.   I opted out of the hibachi specials, but my date ordered the sesame chicken and was quite pleased. Don't be alarmed by the higher than usual prices, the portions can feed 2-3 easily. The sushi was prepared well, although it came out after our meals were already served.   In the past, I've had less than desirable experiences, but this go around, I had no complaint. Great food and good service.
Sorry but l don't think I will return. The waiter could not make hot tea. Slow service and food was mediocre.

Went on valentines day with a group of friends. Our reservation was for 7:30 and our table was ready on time. Our server, I think his name was Steve, was very attentive. Our chef was Luke and he was great. Very engaging and entertaining. The food was great and we had a wonderful evening.

If you are going to attempt to dine here on the weekend, make a reservation. I recommend Luke as your chef. He is very entertaining and his food is the best. I have never had a bad experience here with food or service. My girls, who are 9 and 8, are big fans of Nakama.

I came here last weekend and had a great meal. We sat at the sushi bar and the bartender (I can't remember her name but she was pregnant) was absolutely fantastic. She was super quick and we had wanted mules but she didn't have anymore cups. As soon as one turned up she brought us mules .... on the house! So kind! We enjoyed a lobster role and some tuna sashimi which was to die for. So fresh and delicious. I had such a great night, my boyfriend wanted to come back the following night so it was a winner in my bo

Sat at one of the tables by the window.... I had the cucumber salad, shrimp egg rolls and ahi tuna... All were very delicious! Nice portion of the cucumber salad and the egg rolls were so crispy and the sauce was so yummy!  I'm new to ahi tuna and it was just what I was expecting, I left very happy :) my boyfriend had the shrimp hibachi he cleared the whole plate and not to mention it's really nice you can order hibachi at one of the tables in the front. Our server was nice and she really made sure we had a great time! Can't wait to go back again

I went here with my friends to celebrate joint birthdays and we all decided in checking out this place, because who doesn't love hibachi? Right?!  Anyway we had made reservations for about 15 people and were seated at a hibachi table. Everybody made their drink orders and were given our drinks in a reasonable amount of time.   Hubby and I went for the hibachi, while the majority of our party opted for sushi. Anyway, one of the things that I expect from a hibachi joint is a cheesy, interactive chef and this guy was none of those things. He just basically cooked his dishes and did one onion volcano and that's about it. No crowd interaction or goofy jokes..... this is something I always expect.  Also there were no acknowledgement of anyone's birthday despite telling the waitress.  People that ordered got their fried rice, but I ended up ordering steamed rice, which never arrived when my scallops and steak and veggies had arrived. I was starving at this point so I just proceeded eating and noticed that the waitress did not come back to the table, even to refill drinks. I actually had to flag her down to inquire about my rice. My husband has finished his beer and actually wanted another one but was nowhere to be found. The service was pretty disappointing overall. Another thing that I found disappointing was the small portion size for hibachi. Usually I am used to walking out with left overs for two days from one order of hibachi. The sides were just a small portion of rice, vegetables, and soup and salad, but no lo mein or other hibachi standards.  Not even a small scoop of ice cream at the end.  So needless to say I was kinda bummed out about this too.   In terms of the food I will have to say that my scallops were perfectly cooked, and my steak was pretty awesome, but overall I found the customer service here pretty lacking.  At one point my husband was walking to the bathroom and was nearly run over by a member of the wait staff and didn't even receive an "excuse me".  The lack of service kind of overshadows everything else.   I also think that their decor was pretty cool and really liked their vibe, but overall my experience was just meh.

First time at Nakama and we were really happy with our meals. Hibachi is very good. I had the stir fry vegetables & veggie egg rolls. Egg roll filling wasn't anything to brag about, but they were perfectly crispy on the outside. All of the cocktails we tried were yummy. Valet parking if you need it, but this location on E Carson is relatively easy to find street or paid lot parking. I'd definitely return!

Food was great but as for hibachi preparation it was a low grade. Several errors and a bit plain. Food seasoned well and not over cooked. Location good, and atmosphere good.  Would return but not for the show.

Always on the hunt for something new, we dined at Nakama on a recent Saturday afternoon.  The entrance background is covered in shiny glass tiles.  We were greeted right away and offered a hibachi table or a table in the bar area.  The bar is small and intimate with a few flat screen TV's.  The hibachi area is typical for this type of place and we decided to go with the chef show.  Our server was prompt with our menus and then with our beverages.  I was concerned that we would have to wait for our table to fill.  But our server said that our chef would be out right after our first course.  So, there was only the two of us at our table.  I ordered the shrimp flambe' appetizer, salad and the hibachi shrimp.  The bf ordered the same appetizer, mushroom soup and hibachi chicken.  The soup and salad came out first.  I was impressed by the size of the salad and loved their ginger dressing.  BJ's soup was equally as delicious.    The show was pretty typical of this type of restaurant.  We really enjoyed it and our chef was friendly and very interesting to talk to.  The shrimp were good size and pretty cooked.  The chicken was nicely seasoned and we loved the vegetable friend rice.  Service was a bit off, but the restaurant only recently opened.  We loved our meals and will visit, again!

Sushi came on a regular plate and there was water pooled in the bottom. Sushi was average in freshness and preparation. Crab roll had little flavor and the wrap tasted terrible. Hibachi food (brought to our sushi table) was cold and flavor was bland. My son ordered noodles and they were burned in flavor and tepid at best.  The staff seemed overwhelmed and it was difficult to get things ordered.   Food came out at weird intervals and ordering green tea was a 45 minute wait?????   Nakama use to be better.....probably won't be back.

Hmm...rarely do I return and reduce my rating....never actually. But, this time, I have no choice. The sushi was still good (again, for the area and what we have available to us) and we tried some of our friend's hibachi and the steak was really good - hence the reason I'll still give three stars. This time, I ordered my beloved strawberry citrus-tini martini. While the drink itself was the same, the rim didn't have the same amazing blue sugar. And....there was some sort of hair or something of some sort in my drink...that I discovered AFTER drinking some of the drink. I'm still grossed out by it. Can I, will I return? I'm not so sure.

Stopped at lunch on a dreary Pittsburgh Saturday. They were not crowded and we sat in the bar area. Nice , cool vibe with modern decor. Got the sushi sampler. The fish was nice and fresh. Me and the hubby both got hibachi as well. He got the strip and me the tuna. I enjoyed mine immensely. The hubby though it was just all right. The bar tender was our server as well. She was phenomenal! I wish I could go 3.5 stars but I can't so 3 it is. The hubby thought it was average. I thought it was a little above.

This is a god-awful excuse for a restaurant.  The actual serving of food is last on its list of priorities, which run something like this: 1) Having heavily-made-up waitresses treat diners rudely. 2) Functioning as a place for bald-headed men to drink. 3) Using "valet parking" to totally tie up the intersection of 17th and Carson. 4) Being a mediocre-to-poor Americanized "Japanese" restaurant.  I had sushi the only time I came here (probably about three years ago).  It was really bad.  Cold, rubbery rice that not only didn't have any rice vinegar in it, but wasn't properly cooked.  Rolls looked like they had been created in a fit of pique by a drunken marmot or other mammal lacking opposable thumbs.  And the fish, while not being actively spoiled, was not notable for its freshness either.  If you want hibachi, try Yokoso.  If you want excellent, authentic sushi, try Chaya in Squirrel Hill.  If you want pretty decent, cheap sushi, try Oishii Bento in Oakland.  But for the love of god, don't come here for any reason.

I love Hibachi and Nakama is by far one of the highest quality Hibachis I have ever experienced. I usually get the Hibachi steak. It is cooked to perfection and the shrimp appetizer and yum yum sauce is to die for! They're mixed drinks are fantastic especially the Parasol Girl. Our Chef was very fun and entertaining. They really brought you into the show. Be sure to sign up for their dining card so you can get a meal for free!

I went here for my boyfriend's birthday and did hibachi... and it was good! There was a LOT of food, which is probably why it's so expensive. Hibachi ranges from $20-$70 per person! Plus, they charge you for extras, like $3 extra for fried rice instead of white rice. Kind of ridiculous. The 3 of us shared a bottle of sake because it was $30/bottle so it was the cheapest option. Also, I told 4 people it was his birthday and they were supposed to bring dessert and ring a gong... but that never happened.

This restaurant is AMAZING! My boyfriend and I  went there for dinner & were delighted  by the menu selection the ambiance at first but once our meal came, it was absolutely mind blowing. The sushi was so fresh, so delectible, so DELISH and I think this will be my new "go-to" spot in Pittsburgh for amazing sushi. There are so many more rolls that I would like to try. I cannot wait to return to Pittsburgh to go to Nakama again! :)

This review is only for the sushi bar!  The first time I was here, the sushi tasted AMAZING! The Baked Alaska Roll was topped with salmon that had a smoky taste, which gave the roll an extra kick. I've came back twice to get the same roll, but it no longer had the smoky taste...perhaps it was by accident that the first time tasted so perfect!  I've also had the Boston Roll, Hanalei Roll, Pittsburgh Penguin Roll, and probably a couple more.. don't remember. They consistently have a good balance of ingredients and sauce.   Presentation was great. Last time, I had my rolls spread out on the plate in the shape of a giant flower hehe  Service was always fine, never have to wait too long for the dishes. I always come here if I'm in the area.. even if I've already had dinner, just to get a sushi roll to-go!

Ugh this place is so overrated! It's cool that they cook in front of you and everything but the quality of the food is not great!!! I've been here twice for friends birthday dinners and I don't know why they like it here so much. The service is awful and everything is so overpriced!!! If I never go here again I would be fine with it but I bet one of my girlfriends will drag me here again

We hit up nakama in the southside for my birthday.  Went on a friday night, the crowd wasnt too bad.  Nakama is a place ive been by a bunch of times and always wanted to give it a try.    For the money, what it was, and coming from Westmoreland county it was really not worth it for me.  The habachi was decent but no different than the places in monroeville or greensburg.  We also had sushi was was decent but nothing fantastic.

I used to love nakama and would go all the time. Unfortunately, I will not be going back. The main reason for this is mostly due to the fact that they charge you $4 more for fried rice and don't even include noodles. Meanwhile their prices for most of the hibachi meals are already higher compared to saga or ichiban. Secondly our chef was super average. He didn't do anything cool and didn't even acknowledge that their was a little girl's birthday at our table. But I cannot stress enough how ridiculous it is that they charge you for fried rice. No other hibachi restaurant ever does that, and if they do they at least provide you with noodles. So I ordered the filet mignon and that came with dry terrible white rice and a small portion of vegetables and that came to $28.50.  If you go 5 miles down the road you can go to ichiban and they will give you a combo meal of filet and shrimp with fried rice and noodles for 27.95. Unreal rip off.

No! Just no on the hibachi. The sushi was ok but overshadowed by the horrible experience in the back at the hibachi area that we couldn't really enjoy it. Overpriced, badly cooked...yep, bad hibachi shrimp. Way overdone and chewy. The chicken as well. The "soup" was made from a buillion cube.the salad was a nasty glob of something on some shitty lettuce. And our server was nice and attentive but too busy because they were understaffed. Finally, our hibachi "chef" said not a word nor did he smile. I think maybe he's there against his will. All this for $250! No thanks. Steer clear. They should be out of business soon and something decent in that nice location.
Light dinner just Shrimp and fried rice, but it was Great! The service was good and the Chief was excellent.

I was pretty disappointed with my experience here the other night.  We were there for a birthday dinner and made reservations a week in advance.  When we arrived, we were told it would still be another 15 minutes as they were a little backed up.  We were okay with that, but we didn't end up getting seated until 45 minutes after our reservation.  The hostess then tried to tell us the reason was because our whole part wasn't there, which we all were at the time I checked us is.  So that was a little off-putting that she lied to us.  Our party ordered several glasses of sangria and it was very watered down and not good at all.  We told our waitress who then told us that their sangria does get watered down towards the end of the night.  We all had one drink from the sangria and asked for a different drink.  She got us different drinks, but would not remove the charges for the sangria, even though none of us drank it.    Overall, I was not very satisfied with the service.  I will probably only go there now for the sushi as a takeout item.
The hanalei roll is my favorite sushi roll anywhere ever. Sushi is always fresh. Hibachi  is average. I don't get why people like the atmosphere. I like going here only when it's not very busy.

I've been going to Nakama for years now. I have never thought the hibachi was anything special, especially since you're paying that much for it.   Now onto the sushi, while it isn't fantastic, it is on the better side for Pittsburgh. Definitely not my favorite, but it's consistent and good. Whenever I have a craving and don't want to get all dressed up for the night, Nakama is my go to.   Service is alright here, rarely is it quick, so make sure you have some time to spend. It is definitely pricey, for 4 rolls and 2 beers it was close to $80.

My hubby and I were so happy when this opened nearby because after the change in the taste and serving size of sushi and sashimi at jimmy wan's, there were only a few choices left.  So far our experience here has been great!  The hibachi here is one of the best tasting I've ever had. The chefs are entertaining and service has been consistently good even at the bar area.  You can order sushi at the hibachi section as well.  The bar area is open seating and has quick service.  They have a lot of beer on draft about 20 and good ones too.  I have yet to try their cocktails.    Happy hour is half off appetizers and a dollar off draft beers.  I think also a dollar off some of their martinis?  The last time we dined here, the sushi chef, steve, did a great job on presentation and even came up to our table.  We were also able to use the $10off $50 dinner coupon from the clipper magazine.  They have a good amount of space at the bar area but can get a little crowded at the hibachi area.  Overall, happy with this restaurant and would recommend this place :)

Nakama has the swanky thing down, but otherwise? The food is just par. I've never been impressed with any of the rolls, soups, or appetizers.  Furthermore, I don't like places that DOUSE their sushi in sauces. It's like they're purposely hiding the actual taste of the fish. This place is ok, but nothing really special.

This was my first time dining at Nakama, and our experience was less than ideal. I first made the mistake of believing I could have a calm and quiet meal here on a Saturday night. The restaurant was very loud and hectic. We were seated at a hibachi table with six (clearly intoxicated) people after being denied a non-hibachi table.  The process to get our food took very long, so be prepared to dedicate a good portion of your time just sitting and waiting if it's a weekend night. I ordered the Veggie Roll as a starter. As one of the only appealing vegetarian sushi options on the menu, I decided to give it a try. Overall, it tasted pretty much like any vegetable roll I've had in the past. Nothing too special but decent. For my entree, I ordered the Vegetable Delight with tofu. The tofu was not crispy like I would expect, but still very tasty. The vegetables were cooked and seasoned well. The yum yum sauce stole the show, truthfully. My boyfriend started with the Spicy Typhoon roll which was a disappointment. It was mostly rice and deep-fried batter. For his entree, he ordered the Hibachi Shrimp which is on par with any other hibachi shrimp meal. The portion sizes are big enough to take home and make another meal out of it - always a plus. We opted out of dessert after we were told the only option was freezer burnt chocolate ice cream (A for honesty, I guess)  Overall, the prices were average when it came to the quality of the food, however, the entire experience will probably deter me from returning anytime soon.  FYI, you get a free appetizer if you sign up for their mailing list, but they will not accept it unless the coupon is physically printed out.

Great atmosphere and good bar/wine selection.  Sushi was great. Very yuppie and young professionals crowd.  My only complaint comes from the service.  We were seated at a hibachi table and then told unless the majority of us were getting hibachi we would have to sit at the sushi bar. I wouldn't have had a problem with this but the place was not that crowded and my party of 4 ended up spending a lot of money on sushi and drinks so its difficult for me to understand how they wouldn't accommodate us at a table.  Additionally, they forgot my appetizer and made no effort to apologize at the end of the night.  Great atmosphere, food and location. Improve your service.
Yummy! Clean, lots of options, good beer selection,  nice music playing, great atmosphere, prices were a little high for sushi (about $2 more a roll than usual). Overall nice date night.

It's good. The rolls are better than the sashimi although one time we had some really nice(and surprising) maguro. We always get the hamachi jalape√±o roll and some sashimi so don't get me wrong when I say the rolls are better than the sashimi. It's still enjoyable. Good atmosphere and my girl likes the martinis. Little Tokyo in Mt. Lebanon and Kiku in Station Square are better. Nakama is good for some enjoyable sushi and, more importantly, the atmosphere.  You can go here and watch the pens game AND eat a roll.  Can't say that about a lot of sushi restaurants.  4.5 of 10 relative to sushi quality alone
From the service to the food everything is great. One of my favorite places in the city.

Well... this place has lost it's luster for me. Everything that used to taste high quality and fresh tastes just okay now. The sushi isn't that great anymore. The habachi just isn't the same.  What happened? Did I change? Did this place change? I think it's a little of both. Maybe I can compare it to a relationship. Yes, that's it. Things were awesome at first. We were in love and everything was just perfect. The sushi was fantastic and fresh. The habachi was so delicious I wanted to lick my plate.  Then over time things started to deteriorate. The sushi didn't taste like my beloved Penn Ave Fish, my new amore. The habachi was missing something. Did the soup recipe change? Not as much flavor. Did the portions get smaller. Where did my sprouts go?! Things started to head south...  The last straw was the whole atmosphere or Club Nakama we'll call it. The music is pulsating techno. The crowd is judge-y. The service is lacking. And the food, it's nothing special. Sad, because what once was, is no more:(  It's time to break-up. We had a good run. We may run into each other once in a while and be friendly, but for now, it's time we take a break. Might be for good this time. You never know....

Stopped here after having a disappointing happy hour somewhere else.    Surprised happy hour went later than typical.  Food and drinks was good, and fair prices.    Chill atmosphere, and bar staff had good timing.

This is your typical hibachi place.  The Spider roll was a lot of imitation crab meat, but it was very nicely rolled and presented well. It was a slightly crunchy soft shell crab.  We shared a triple combo and the chef was confused? / annoyed? that we were sharing...but we were glad we did in the end...between the two of us, we STILL had food left over.  Started us each out with a bowl of miso soup, and it had fried onions and mushrooms in it, which was different, and appreciated.  The salad was good with a yummy sauce and mixed greens, carrots and tomatoes. On the better side of the salads I've had like this.  Our combo had steak, shrimp, and chicken...and it was just... a TON of rice and a tonnn of veggies. It was delicious, but as usual it was on the saltier side. That is hibachi for you, though. Pretty good.  Our server didn't really put on a show. Not sure if he knew English that well. He did all the demos, but didn't interact with us too much as I've been used to in the past.

All I had here was sushi which I found to be okay. Between the two of us, we got the Boston Roll and the Rainbow Roll. Rainbow roll was really good, except one of the pieces of fish tasted a bit slimy to me, so that was a little unsettling. Rest of the roll was great, however. The Boston roll though was very underwhelming. It was supposed to have cream cheese in it, but for the life of us, we could not taste the cream cheese! How are you going to advertise cream cheese as one of your key ingredients when there's basically no cream cheese except for maybe in one measly piece? Quite disappointing.  Service was good. Our waitress was nice, quick, and efficient. Just how servers should be. A little on pricier side though, so watch for that.  Bottom line: sushi-wise, this place is okay. I won't be craving it, but if someone were to invite me out to dinner there, I wouldn't put up a fuss. It's not a place I would go out of my way to eat at.

Atmosphere is nice.  Made reservations right from the app and we went straight to our table.  We had a new waitress, but she wasn't bad.  We ordered and our sushi was out in probably 10 min!  Very fast for the amount we ordered.  The presentation and taste were both excellent.  All around a good sushi/hibachi

Stopped by here today for food during OpenStreetsPGH! Prices are a little expensive but also sushi is usually expensive in general, especially at restaurants like these.  I got the dragon roll and my friend got the Hawaiian style roll. They were good but not anything spectacular. I think my check came out to around $16 for my one roll alone.   Service was really nice and attentive since they weren't super busy. However, the table we sat at had a spilled soy sauce puddle and a soaked menu. And the little side dishes for sauces were dirty and not cleaned well. It's disappointing because this seems like a "fancier" establishment that would focus on keeping their tables/dishes clean.

A group of four of us went to dinner before a show in the south side. We alerted our server to our time window and she said no problem. Our servers attentiveness was minimal and we didn't require a lot. Our meals were okay but nothing special. When the bills came our prices were different than on the menu and when we asked our server about it she told us that we each had a $3.50 up charge for ordering fried rice rather than the white rice the meals came with. Our server never mentioned the up charge and she asked us which type of rice we would prefer! She was very rude about it in the end and never apologized or anything. We will spend our money elsewhere when we go to the next show.

I go here a few times a month, mostly because I think the bar scene is probably one of the most fun in Pittsburgh.   It gets pretty crowded especially on the weekends, but the staff does a good job especially after you go there a few times and they know who you  are.  It's the only place I know of in Pittsburgh that on any given day (even a monday or tuesday) there will be a good crowd at the bar with a higher girl to guy ratio than the usual dudefest at most bars.  The hibachi is better than most.  It's definitely better than benihana, but probably not as good as Shogun in Monroeville.  The only thing I don't like about the hibachi (or any hibachi) is that after the meal you smell like a diner short order cook because of the oil from the grill.  The other menu items are pretty average at best.  The marinated beef tips and chicken lettuce wraps are okay appetizers.  The edaname is pretty hard to mess up and the miso soup is about average.  The sushi is awful.  I mean I guess the rolls are edible, but you can hide the quality by adding a lot of junk to cover up the flavor.  The sashimi (whish is really all that I order) I found to be really poor quality and the way it was sliced was not at all how sashimi should be sliced.  I really don't understand how this place wins best overall restaurant and best sushi  in Pittsburgh.  It really makes no sense.  Most of the people I know agree that the hibachi is good, but overall the restaurant isn't that good and the sushi not good at all.  However, I have a  friend who is one of the chefs assures me that the quality of ingredient is good.  Overall, I suggest if you eat here the hibachi is pretty good and fun if  you are having a sit down dinner.  If you are eating at the bar try to stick to the edamame or maybe one of the appetizers mentioned.  I strongly suggest staying away from the sushi, but if you  must stick to the most basic of rolls (california roll, etc.).  In fact, if you are not sitting down for hibachi go eat at Dish on the same street and head to Nakama only for the bar.

I went to the hibachi with a few friends here on a weeknight, and I didn't try the sushi so I can't speak to it.  It was pretty packed and indeed, it was very loud and very dark.  You seriously might want to bring a flashlight to read the menu (I'm not joking).  There were only 4 of us at the hibachi table, so the  fun factor was pretty dulled down, but it didn't help that you couldn't really hear what the guy was trying to say anyway.  The server had a hard time hearing me as well, but my order of chicken was correct.  So as for the food: Salad - was well saturated with ginger dressing -I mean they must have tossed it with a good amount of dressing before bringing it out.  The dressing was good, but definitely not that good.  Soup - salted and fine, nothing notable. Shrimp flambe - chewy, tasteless, didn't even have the butter flavor. Rice - steamed and fine Chicken and veggies - dry dry dry chicken, veggies were good, and the flavors on the veggies were very good.   Sauces - okay The ladies room: Pretty clean, and also staffed.  Bottom line for me - I wouldn't come back here on my own volition - there are other places in Pgh I would try first.

Way Way Way over-rated.  This is not a place to have an enjoyable dinner.  However, if your'e the type of a person who loves shaving your face with alcohol, then this is a place for you.  This place is noisy and dark.  I could hardly read the menu but luckily I reviewed the menu online before I went.  The food price is outrageous but if your goal was to impress a date, then that's fine.  Then again, why would you want to bring a date here since you will have a hard time talking to him/her since this place is so noisy.  The Hibachi chef that we ended up with looked like a Mexican that could hardly speak English.  His skill sucks and couldn't even do the onion volcano correctly.  This is the very basic thing and looking at him trying to make one is pathetic.
Nakama has OK sushi.   Nakama is noisy, the waiters take forever to serve you, and it's way overpriced. If you want authentic sushi go to CHAYA THE BEST SUSHI IN THE BURGH!

$60 for takeout and I've had better food from the #1 ChinaHouse. Portion sizes were stingy and a joke for the price - It's like there was a nationwide shortage of shrimp. $4 for mushroom flambe that consisted of 8 sliced up pieces(total rip off). Tastes were bland and non-existent - onion soup tasted like Swanson beef broth straight out of the can. Things were left out of the order no soy sauce for the California roll, no chopsticks, and total lack of service. I would expect more from a so-called 5 star Japanese Steakhouse. I work hard for my money and will never waste it again on this hype. Save your time and money and just go to Ichiban.

Disclaimer: This is review is for the SUSHI BAR ONLY   Went here last Saturday and stopped in for a quick bite at the sushi bar, mainly to try it out because I've heard so many good things about Nakama.   To be honest, my experience was exactly like the two star Yelp rating means: Meh. I've experienced better.  Two of the 4 rolls I ordered were loosely made which as a sushi lover I found to be kinda unacceptable. One had an end piece that frankly would have gotten the sushi chef a failing grade by anyone's standards - it was falling apart and had nothing but rice and paper on it despite this being a fairly pricey signature roll. One of my sushi pieces was similarly falling apart - the rice hadn't been packed enough and the salmon was just slapped on there.   I would even have sent those back if I could have found a waitress or been able to hear myself think. They were just too crowded to give the proper amount of love to each dish, and as you know, a dish prepared without love is bound to be lacking.  The noise and my seat in relation to the crowded door area just made me want to get out of there. I was bumped several times by people weaving their way past each other, at one point someone bumped my elbow as I was raising a cup of hot sake. Hmm ... a splash of hot sake? ... let's say it's not my favorite sensation in the crotch area.  Anyway, the staff was friendly when you were able to flag someone down and I am sure everyone was doing their best, but think this place is highly overrated - making it over crowded - making the whole experience that much less enjoyable for everyone.  Hope your experience is better than mine - the place should have been better from what I've been told by Nakama fans. Good luck!!

It's just ok. Not something I'll come back to or recommend. The sushi was plain and simple, not tasty but not bad. Some sushi places are simply dangerous, but this place seems safe but boring.   Overall, if you have a choice, take a pass.

I really thought that Nakama was a great place.   We went there for Valentines day. They had great specials and they also provided a complimentary rose with your reservation. It really seemed like they cared about the little details.   The restaurant was very clean and decorated nicely. It has a large bar and sushi in the front. I really liked the open design and tall ceilings because it gave the feeling of having a lot of space.   The wait staff was very friendly and very prompt with service and bringing drinks.   I wouldn't say that it was any more busy/noicey then any other hibachi type restaurant. These always draw crowds and tend to be noisy. The pricing is also on par with any other restaurant of this type.   If I had a complaint was it did take a little long for our cook to come out.  They did serve soup and salad quickly.   I would go again and recommend it to friends.
